An Android is something that is not a phone. Which is actually an appropriate name, because nobody uses phones as phones anymore.

Whether Android is the superior mobile/cell phone OS is less interesting than whether mobile/cell phone manufacturers should be tarred and feathered for forcing their customers to buy newer models sooner than technologically necessary by not making OS updates available for "older" models.

Prices for these gadgets are way too high, their ecological impact during production and especially their disposal too big, to make replacing them semiannually sensible, just to receive an up-to-date OS - not that the newest version of OS were any less prone to security faults, but still ...

An operating system by itself has no value without the software that runs under its control. So, any operating system is as good for end users as good the software is. Sooo, between the two I find little differences. Both offer any service I might ever find useful. Of course, Android is more flexible in some ways, I like my smartphone acts as a flash drive when I need to transfer files to or from it which iOS doesn't allow, as I understand. Apart from that, the choice between the two is a matter of aesthetic preferences.
